contentrichtext.text: {{For|the Bridge over the [[River Tyne]]|Bambuco Bridge}} {{Unreferenced|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox music genre |name=Bambuco |color=white |bgcolor=brown |stylistic_origins= [[Indigenous peoples in Colombia|Indigenous Music of Colombia]], [[Waltz|European Waltz]], [[Afro-Colombian|Afro-Colombian Music Heritage]], |cultural_origins= [[Andean Region of Colombia]] |instruments=[[Tiple#Colombian tiple|Tiple]] - [[Guitar]] - [[Piano]] - [[Requinto]] - [[Bandola]] - [[Tambora (Colombian drum)|Tambora]] - [[Vocals]] |popularity=High in [[Colombia]] since the 1800s. <br /> Medium in [[Venezuela]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]] and [[Mexico]] |subgenres=Sanjuanero - Bambuco Fiestero |fusiongenres= Bambuco Jazz }} '''Bambuco''' is a traditional music genre originated from [[Colombia]]. It has a [[beat (music)|beat]] structure similar to the [[Europe]]an [[waltz]] or [[polska (dance)|polska]] (not to be confused with the [[polka]]). Typically a '''bambuco''' piece is a [[folk music]] song accompanied by a stylized [[group dance]] in either a 6/8 or 3/4 [[metre (music)|meter]]. Bambuco took a cultural foothold in the [[Andes|Andean region]] of Colombia and has spread in popularity throughout [[Latin America]].
